historicalFigures.name: Ibn Saud
historicalFigures.nativeName: Abdulaziz ibn Abdul Rahman Al Saud
historicalFigures.background: Ibn Saud was the founder and first monarch of Saudi Arabia. He united the tribes of the Arabian Peninsula and established the modern kingdom in 1932.
keyDecisions: Signing the oil concession with Standard Oil of California.
Meeting FDR on the USS Quincy.
historicalFigures.legacy: Ibn Saud is the father of the nation. Every subsequent king has been his son.
quotes: My kingdom will survive only insofar as it remains a country difficult to access.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is the central figure of Saudi history.
modernInterpretations: Revered as a great unifier.
His alliance with Wahhabism defined the state.

historicalFigures.name: Prophet Muhammad
historicalFigures.background: Muhammad is the founder of Islam and the messenger of God in Islamic belief. Born in Mecca, he united Arabia under a single religious polity.
historicalFigures.legacy: Muhammad is the most influential person in history (Hart's list). Islam is the world's second-largest religion.
quotes: I have been sent to perfect good character.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: His life (Sunnah) is the model for billions.
modernInterpretations: Revered as the perfect human.
His teachings are the foundation of Islamic law.

historicalFigures.name: Faisal of Saudi Arabia
historicalFigures.background: Faisal was the King of Saudi Arabia from 1964 to 1975. He is known for modernizing the country and leading the 1973 oil embargo.
keyDecisions: Leading the oil embargo against the West.
historicalFigures.legacy: Faisal is the most popular Saudi king. He is seen as a wise and strong leader.
quotes: We and our ancestors survived on dates and milk and we will return to them again.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: King Faisal Foundation is a major philanthropic organization.
modernInterpretations: Celebrated as a hero of the Arab world.
His assassination is a national tragedy.

historicalFigures.name: Khadija bint Khuwaylid
historicalFigures.background: Khadija was the first wife of Prophet Muhammad and the first convert to Islam. She was a wealthy and successful merchant in Mecca.
keyDecisions: Hiring Muhammad to manage her caravans.
historicalFigures.legacy: Khadija is the ideal woman in Islam. She proved that women could be powerful and pious.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: She is a role model for Muslim women.
modernInterpretations: Celebrated as a strong, independent woman.
Her love story with Muhammad is legendary.

historicalFigures.name: Mohammed bin Salman
historicalFigures.background: Mohammed bin Salman is the Crown Prince and de facto ruler of Saudi Arabia. He is driving the Vision 2030 plan to diversify the economy and modernize society.
historicalFigures.legacy: MBS is reshaping Saudi Arabia. He is a polarizing figure—reformer to some, autocrat to others.
quotes: We are returning to what we were before—a country of moderate Islam.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is popular among the youth.
modernInterpretations: Viewed as the future of the kingdom.
His human rights record is heavily criticized.

historicalFigures.name: Umar ibn al-Khattab
historicalFigures.background: Umar was the second Caliph of Islam. Under his leadership, the Islamic empire expanded at an unprecedented rate, conquering Persia and Byzantium.
historicalFigures.legacy: Umar is the architect of the Islamic Empire. His justice is legendary.
quotes: Since when have you enslaved people when their mothers bore them free?
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is a model of good governance.
modernInterpretations: Revered as a genius administrator.
Sunnis and Shias have different views on him.

historicalFigures.name: Ghazi al-Gosaibi
historicalFigures.background: Ghazi al-Gosaibi was a politician, diplomat, and writer. He served as Minister of Health and Labor and was a liberal voice in a conservative society.
keyDecisions: Writing controversial novels ('An Apartment Called Freedom').
historicalFigures.legacy: Al-Gosaibi is the conscience of the modern state. He fought for efficiency and openness.
quotes: The bureaucrat is the enemy of development.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: His books are widely read. He inspired a generation of technocrats.
modernInterpretations: Celebrated as a visionary.
His wit and courage are missed.

historicalFigures.name: Muhammad ibn Abd al-Wahhab
historicalFigures.background: Ibn Abd al-Wahhab was a religious leader who founded the Wahhabi movement. He allied with Muhammad bin Saud to establish the first Saudi state.
keyDecisions: Forming an alliance with the House of Saud (1744).
historicalFigures.legacy: His pact with the Saud family defines Saudi Arabia to this day. His legacy is global and controversial.
quotes: I call to the oneness of God.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: His interpretation of Islam dominates the country.
modernInterpretations: Revered by Salafis.
Criticized by others for extremism.

historicalFigures.name: Zaha Hadid
historicalFigures.background: Though Iraqi, Zaha Hadid's influence in Saudi Arabia is profound, notably the King Abdullah Petroleum Studies and Research Center (KAPSARC) and the Riyadh Metro station.
keyDecisions: Designing King Abdullah Financial District Metro Station.
Pushing the boundaries of design in the desert.
historicalFigures.legacy: Her buildings are symbols of the new Saudi Arabia. She proved that futuristic design belongs in the desert.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: KAPSARC is a global icon of sustainability.
modernInterpretations: Celebrated as a genius.
Her work fits the Vision 2030 aesthetic.

historicalFigures.name: Raja'a Al Sanea
historicalFigures.background: Raja'a Al Sanea is a writer and endodontist. Her novel 'Girls of Riyadh' caused a sensation by exposing the hidden lives of young Saudi women.
achievements: Opened the door for Saudi women writers.
historicalFigures.legacy: Al Sanea broke the silence. She showed the world the reality of Saudi women's lives.
quotes: I wanted to write about the real Riyadh.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: Her book is the 'Sex and the City' of Saudi Arabia.
modernInterpretations: Celebrated as brave.
Her work is now mainstream.

historicalFigures.name: Majed Abdullah
historicalFigures.background: Majed Abdullah is a former footballer known as the 'Arabian Jewel'. He is the all-time top scorer for the Saudi national team and Al Nassr FC.
keyDecisions: Staying with Al Nassr his whole career.
Leading Saudi Arabia to the 1984 & 1988 Asian Cups.
achievements: Asian Footballer of the Year (3 times).
challenges: Lack of professional structure (at the time).
historicalFigures.legacy: Majed is the greatest Saudi footballer ever. He put Saudi football on the map.
quotes: I played for the love of the game.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is adored by fans of all clubs.
modernInterpretations: Celebrated as the GOAT.
His records are hard to beat.

historicalFigures.name: Lubna Olayan
historicalFigures.background: Lubna Olayan is a business tycoon and the former CEO of Olayan Financing Company. She was the first woman to deliver a keynote address at a major conference in Saudi Arabia.
keyDecisions: Advocating for women in the workforce.
achievements: First woman to chair a Saudi listed bank.
historicalFigures.legacy: Lubna Olayan is the face of Saudi businesswomen. She proved that women can lead at the highest level.
quotes: I don't believe in quotas. I believe in merit.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: She inspired a generation of female entrepreneurs.
modernInterpretations: Respected as a titan of industry.
Her leadership is exemplary.

historicalFigures.name: Antarah ibn Shaddad
historicalFigures.background: Antarah was a pre-Islamic Arab knight and poet, famous for his poetry and his adventurous life. He was born a slave (son of an Ethiopian mother) and won his freedom through bravery.
keyDecisions: Refusing to be treated as a slave.
achievements: Author of one of the Seven Mu'allaqat.
historicalFigures.legacy: Antarah is the ultimate Arab hero. His story of love and war is the Arab Iliad.
quotes: If I am black, my deeds are white.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: His story is told in coffee shops to this day.
modernInterpretations: Celebrated as a symbol of overcoming prejudice.
His poetry is a masterpiece.

historicalFigures.name: King Abdullah
historicalFigures.background: Abdullah was the King of Saudi Arabia from 2005 to 2015. He was known as a reformer who promoted dialogue and education.
keyDecisions: Launching the King Abdullah Scholarship Program.
Appointing women to the Shura Council.
historicalFigures.legacy: King Abdullah is the 'Education King'. His scholarship program changed Saudi society forever.
quotes: Do not forget me in your prayers.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is remembered with great affection.
modernInterpretations: Viewed as a father figure.
His era was one of prosperity.

historicalFigures.name: Haifaa al-Mansour
historicalFigures.background: Haifaa al-Mansour is the first female Saudi filmmaker. Her film 'Wadjda' was the first feature film shot entirely in Saudi Arabia and the first submitted for an Oscar.
keyDecisions: Directing 'Wadjda' (from a van to avoid being seen).
historicalFigures.legacy: Haifaa put Saudi cinema on the map. She proved that Saudi stories matter.
quotes: I want to show the human side of Saudi Arabia.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: She inspired a new wave of filmmakers.
modernInterpretations: Celebrated as a trailblazer.
Her work is critical but loving.

historicalFigures.name: Prince Sultan bin Salman
historicalFigures.background: Prince Sultan is the first Arab, first Muslim, and first royal to fly in space. He flew on the Space Shuttle Discovery in 1985.
achievements: Youngest person to fly on the Shuttle.
historicalFigures.legacy: Sultan bin Salman is the face of Saudi science. He inspired the new space program.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: He is a symbol of progress.
modernInterpretations: Celebrated as a pioneer.
He remains active in public life.

historicalFigures.name: Thoraya Obaid
historicalFigures.background: Thoraya Obaid was the Executive Director of the UNFPA. She was the first Saudi national to head a UN agency.
historicalFigures.legacy: Thoraya Obaid showed that Saudi women belong on the global stage.
quotes: Culture is created by people, and people can change it.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: She is a respected voice in development.
modernInterpretations: Celebrated as a pioneer.
Her wisdom is sought after.

historicalFigures.name: Safeya Binzagr
historicalFigures.background: Safeya Binzagr is a pioneer of Saudi art. She is known for documenting Saudi folklore and traditional dress in her paintings.
keyDecisions: Opening her own museum (Darat Safeya Binzagr).
achievements: First Saudi woman to hold a solo exhibition.
historicalFigures.legacy: Safeya Binzagr preserved the visual history of Saudi Arabia. Her museum is a treasure.
historicalFigures.culturalImpact: She is the mother of Saudi art.
primarySources: Saudi Arabia: An Artist's View of the Past.
modernInterpretations: Revered as a cultural guardian.
Her work is essential for history.
